comments.commentBody: Great series. I see you did the audio before shooting the pictures. I wonder what would have happened if you did the reverse.

It is now routine for neighbors to sue each other over trival complaints.  We subvert our coworkers to get ahead in our increasingly mean workplaces.  Parents swear and yell epithets and opposing school teams.  Mothers subvert competing cheerleaders who threaten their own children's chances.  What's the outrage against these two individuals all about?  We should be outraged with ourselves for letting our society crumble while we focus on our selfish lives.

For those interested, you can email the president of Rutgers at the campus where this happened to ask whether they have expelled the students who committed these crimes and what they are doing to ensure the safety of students there in the future. His email is president@rutgers.edu.

We do not know if it was a hate a crime.

It may have been a heinous hate crime. But also it may not have been an act of hate but of thoughtlessness.

It is conceivable that one or both of the culprits are so remorseful that all this outpouring of hate and lynch mob mentality may be misplaced. If they are remorseful it may lead to their suicide, which would be dreadful. If that happens then all those casting stones will look in the mirror and see the monster that they accuse the perpetrators to be.

Or they may the monsters that many say they are, the haters that deserve to be put away for a long time. We simply do not know at this point, we do not have enough information.

Let justice be done but lets not prejudge before all the facts are in. There is too much sadness with what happened now. Lets think the family of the young musician and extend our heartfelt sympathy. I do not think we are honoring the victim by lashing out until we know the details where both God and the Devil co-inhabit.

The tweets Mr. Ravi wrote show pretty clearly that he knew of the encounters beforehand, purposely broadcast them and meant to embarrass his roommate by revealing his sexuality. I'm not sure this makes the case a hate crime but the intent is there.
The fact that the two were roommates makes this even more upsetting. It's easy to prank a stranger. It's much harder to humiliate someone who you know to be shy, sensitive and obviously conflicted, and who you'll presumably be seeing and interacting with every day for the whole semester. These are legal adults who lacked the empathy and foresight to realize they were making a poor decision. Rutgers is trying to teach civility in the online space and they did it anyway. Do not blame the technology or the parents. Unless these two can prove they meant no harm, (which I doubt) hold them responsible for their actions and hope the rest learn the lesson.
I have no sympathy for the two students who so cruelly exposed Mr.Clementi. They should be prosecuted to the full extent of the law. And I hope they are ashamed of themselves forever.

I want these two students expelled from Rutgars. Their transcripts should have a disclosure and detailed explanations as to why they were kicked out. Unless it's some small Christian college in the South that believes in redemption, no school would take these two ever. And I believe they deserve it.

I certainly think that these two should be charged with more than "invasion of privacy." Rutgers should permanently expel these two insensitive bigots and should put the reason in their permanent Rutgers files so future potential employers can be made aware of their behavior. If the victim had poor self-esteem it certainly is understandable considering the bigotry and discrimination he had to endure. Yes we certainly "Can... blame the suspects for the kid's lack of self-esteem?"

I go to Rutgers in a non-traditional status. I'm 25 and while that may not be a significant difference in age from the people involved in this terrible situation, it is enough of a distance that I see the growing immaturity in the students coming in to college. Kids entering college are brutal to other students. I have my own friends and have no desire to make friends with the other students that I go to school with. I consider myself lucky because now you can't be yourself around people, you have to drastically change your character in order to fit in. The is an awful situation that never should have happened. It's a sign that something needs to be done to change the glaring immaturity in today's young adults.

What a tragedy.  I feel for the poor young artist who had to live out his last days in fear and anguish.  The two students who posted the video aren't the only guilty ones here.  All the other kids, the voyeurs who sat in front of their computers and watched it play out live like a snuff film, played a role as well.  We need to teach our children that we can't always prevent people from being cruel, but we must do our best to try and mitigate the damage.

Note to the prosecutor:  Please take into account the exact words in the message that was posted by the perpetrators of this horrible crime: They turned the web cam on remotely.  It was not left on and observed 'by accident'.  Instead, they admit that they proactively turned on a recording device that had otherwise been left in the "off" position.  They did so specifically to violate the privacy of an unsuspecting victim.  As I understand the law, it would appear that their crime was therefore premeditated.  How many years does that add to their jail time?  Many, I hope.

How tragic!  I am appalled that anyone would humiliate another person like this.  Here in Helena, our school district had introduced a new curriculum for health education that included teaching our youth that some people might love other people of the same gender.  This caused some hysteria amongst those that fear a homosexual agenda might replace standard curriculum.  The curriculum has been modified to reduce some of the hysteria.  This horrible incident makes me think our school board was on the right track!

A person has a right to protect their property, what if the roommate thought another was stealing something and was watching a live video feed? We have to allow such monitoring to continue, no matter the consequences.A sad death indeed, but not intentional.

First of all, this was an act of thoughtless cruelty by Tyler's 18-year-old room-mate. Unfortunately, an act that is kind of typical for that age group; teens are neurologically lacking in empathy and lack as well the common-sense borne of experience. In this respect, it's as much a social issue. Teenagers are what they are - and how do society and families supervise them/control them/ guide them/ nourish the milk of human kindness/ punish what needs to be punished/ until they mature?
The girl was a party to the act by letting her next-door-room be used, but apparently not an instigator. As far as can be told by reading the NYT (let a jury decide).
Immature perps or not, a crime was committed - the violation of privacy. The result (suicide) may have been unforeseen, but given the homophobia prevalent in this society, certainly it was clear that Tyler was intended to suffer severe embarrassment.
Which of course brings me to the truly pathetic and medieval outlook on sexuality of the religious Right and its Republican sidekicks - who have in no small way contributed to perpetuating a bit of the dark ages into the 21st century.

"Get a thicker skin" when someone is dead? What an awful thing to say. I'm also puzzled and alarmed by the posts saying Clementi was "obviously" sick or otherwise mentally unstable. We don't know that. We know he was 18, a musician, and, from the sound of things, exploring his sexuality. We also know he had a jerk of a roommate. That's all.

It's not a hate crime; it's worse. It's a crime of apathy, of utter insensitivity to another's feelings. These things are happening all over--I'm from Missouri, where a woman bullied a 13 year old girl via MySpace until she committed suicide. It was one of the more evil acts I can recall--and I do not use the word lightly--yet by the law, there wasn't much that could be done to prosecute her. Same here. Any laws developed have to reactive, since the magnitude of the bully's actions is often measured by the reaction of the victim. Could preventative laws be put in place? It's not a rhetorical question.

Finally, let's leave the perpetrators' parents out of this. Nature and nurture interact in strange and unpredictable ways; we have no idea how they were raised. Let the responsibility for their actions lie with them and them alone.

I feel bad for Tyler Clementi and his family; however, I find it awfully self-righteous that individuals on this forum are expressing the need for immediate and severe vengeance.  Bullying is pretty common and has been for a very long time.  I have been bullied, and I am at least aware that there were moments in my life where I, myself, was the bully.  The difference now, with technological innovation, is that our medium of communication has shifted, including that of bullying (which is essentially a form a of a communicative exchange.)  Does this either excuse or justify their behavior?  No it does not.  However, the Tyler's decision to commit suicide is, in a sense, mutually exclusive from the action that was directed against him.  His decision to commit suicide should be independently treated, just like their action to bully someone.  In my opinion, this should not be treated differently than bullying in a school environment (which could also lead to suicide or other destructive behavior).  Now that we have equated it, all of you righteous forum posters should consider every moment you bullied and humiliated someone, and imagine if those actions could have resulted in the victim's suicide.  I am sure most of you can, and, if not, I am sure you can identify with someone else who can (e.g. a brother, a friend, a spouse etc.)  This country needs to step off its high horse and call a spade a spade.

Well-meaning people I know say they have little sympathy for victims who would kill themselves over this or other forms of bullying and mockery, because it didn't make them suicidal.

I remember how I used to be bullied in junior high school because I came from a different background, didn't speak English and wore 'uncool' clothes. I overcame it then through top grades and a selective memory which somehow blotted it out completely until my mother reminded me of it.

This was back in the 70's. Today, with a video of the same actions on the web that lives forever, would I have been as capable of ignoring it? and would good grades or other virtues in today's value system inspire respect from classmates as it once did?

Discussions are a positive and necessary step. Our cultures profits are generated by abuse of others via ripping them off, ( to begin with not paying them a living wage, and not supporting The Public Option for health care)belittling the harm done to others (all the crass trash talk and lies polluting the airwaves and media)and taking advantage of anyone who is vulnerable (major health insurance companies deciding that it is not cost effective to treat people and letting them die via stall tactics. This happened to my friends father.)

We have a callous, murderous culture of Cains.

Let's declare a War on Terror, a War on Fear and a War on Selfishness. This war is fought internally to master ones own worst impulses.

Tragic.

In this age of hi-tech electronic products we are immersed in, checks need to be in place, to prevent other similar, "starring roles"
Since it is unlikely, that people will change their characteristics, and not enjoy voyeuristic pursuits, even to the extent of causing such anguish to another human being, such suffering to result in suicide, monitors, or better yet, impediments, built into the electronics themselves, should ideally be utilized.

That too, is farfetched.

The roommate responsible for the chain of events, ending in Mr. Clementi's suicide, needs counseling.
Counseling on basics, such as respect, for privacy, decency and the like.
Unfortunately, too many people of all ages,all walks of life, are amoral.

That's how this tragedy could happen.

My sympathy, to the family of Mr. Clementi.

This is such a sad story. A beautiful life filled with promise gone forever.Why, because a couple of freaks thought it would be funny to video him having sex? There is so much sadness and hate in the world that we can not control. It breaks my heart to know that an other generation of bullies and mean girls are being bred everyday. I truly hope the judge throws the book at these two and gives them the max.I also hope they live long healthy lives, giving them plenty of time to reflect on the one event that shaped their lives, their families and most of all, Tyler.

Although it's more Draconian than I usually think the world should be, there needs to be a bigger sense of shame among young people.  Or perhaps it's humility.  In any event, if these kids' (and those like them--there are plenty) individual consciousnesses can't control their behavior, let the collective consciousness do it.  Put them in jail for 5 years, but shame them for life.  Scarlet letter style.  Yes, 18 year old's are kids, but they're well on their way to becoming adults.  Unacceptable.  Maybe Durkheim was right, after all.

This is a terrible tragedy, however sending these two 18 year old children to jail would only further the pain and suffering. Clearly what they did was wrong, and they will be haunted by this forever. The idea that what they did is murder, as some comments have insinuated, is ludicrous. How could they have possibly predicted their actions could have led to Mr. Clementi's death? One cant draw a direct draw a line from a) what they did to b) Clementi's suicide. Was he already depressed? How was his family life? Its easy to vilify these two, but we really don't know all the facts of this case, so why be so quick to judge?

Rather than crucify these two clearly misguided, immature teenagers we need to concentrate on how to reach out to students who feel alienated and alone amongst our 55000 student body.

-A disappointed Rutgers Student

And another tragedy that was only possible through the immediacy of technology, where significant, long-lasting and devastating consequences can come from a momentary decision, a momentary inspiration. A thoughtless moment; without foresight, and generally without foreseeable consequences a petty, casual (however mean-spirited, but not abnormally so) gesture can result in irreversible loss. This situation just happened to have a sensational conclusion.

"When a sin is not forgiven, it requires punishment, it cries to people or to God for punishment; but when a sin cries for punishment, it looks entirely different, much greater than when the same sin is forgiven. Is this merely an optical illusion? No, it is actually so. To use an inadequate metaphor, it is no optical illusion that the wound that looked so appalling looks much less appalling the moment the physician has washed and taken care of it, and yet it is the same wound. What, then, does the one do who denies forgiveness? He enlarges the sin, makes it seem greater. Furthermore, forgiveness deprives the sin of life, but to deny forgiveness provides the sin with sustenance." - Kierkegaard

Darn it ! I've been sensing this for a number of years now. Despite the overall crime rate being down, our society has become coarser in a number of respects. You see it on the road, in the anger I've sensed in peoples conversations with one another, ( that is when they are actually speaking to one another!), and in the day to day observations I have seen on the street, and in a number of venues I participate in. This negative atmosphere has filtered down to our young people, who in many instances lack the role models they once looked to. On top of this, the current media goes out of its' way to find instances where people are behaving in an obnoxious manner, and by highlighting it, such things are becoming more of the accepted norm. I was very concerned a number of years back, when the series "Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous" became popular, creating in peoples minds, that if they didn't possess the material things, they would be deemed lacking. This was followed by that "Show me the Money' phrase which became ubiquitous from the Tom Cruise movie, it flowed from. Put all these things together, and you come up with a new generation influenced, not by the lofty ideals of our historic, which in many ways helped build character, Judaic-Christian roots, but rather values which would always lead to an empty fortress, and a banal existence. Sure it's important to put an emphasis on math and science, and having a job, but if we forget our humanity, indeed our historic civilty, what kind of country and people will we become? Till we start emphasizing the social sciences, since we don't have the stability of the family anymore, we will only head to the same fate that Rome encountered! This was a tragedy. Wake up America!

What a terrible thing!  My prayers go to the family of Mr. Clementi.  As for the two who committed this act, I hope that they are punished in a way that brings home to them the suffering that they have caused.  Maybe prison will do them some good.   At the very least they should be expelled instantly from Rutgers.  If the University keeps them enrolled then it must share the responsibility for this crime.
